text: Hi all, I have managed to collect some horse racing data (huge thanks to <@U4H19D1D2>’s flumine!) for the past month, and am trying to setup backtesting with flumine. I saw this backtest example <https://liampauling.github.io/flumine/quickstart#backtesting> passing one market/file (1.170212754?) to the flumine. I was trying to find a way to pass the entire folder of recorded data to flumine, but with no luck. Please could someone give me a pointer? Many thanks.

elements.text: Hi all, I have managed to collect some horse racing data (huge thanks to
’s flumine!) for the past month, and am trying to setup backtesting with flumine. I saw this backtest example

passing one market/file (1.170212754?) to the flumine. I was trying to find a way to pass the entire folder of recorded data to flumine, but with no luck. Please could someone give me a pointer? Many thanks.

text:
Hey so I'm trying to pull all my trades. If I'm understanding right, I can use Trading.betting.currentorders to grab all my current orders, filled or not, and then when an order has been "completed" I know that all my volume has traded there. BUT, I don't think I can tell when an order has been partially filled, except by keeping track myself of the volume that's left, and using subtracting to know how much volume got partially filled.

Is there another table I'm missing that will just return me all my trades that actually happened? Basically looking for this:

elements.text:
Hey so I'm trying to pull all my trades. If I'm understanding right, I can use Trading.betting.currentorders to grab all my current orders, filled or not, and then when an order has been "completed" I know that all my volume has traded there. BUT, I don't think I can tell when an order has been partially filled, except by keeping track myself of the volume that's left, and using subtracting to know how much volume got partially filled.

Is there another table I'm missing that will just return me all my trades that actually happened? Basically looking for this:

text: Like, all my trades that have actually happened, the time, the price they were at, etc.

elements.text: Like, all my trades that have actually happened, the time, the price they were at, etc.

text: Hi. I’m a non bflw user at the moment. My coding strength is C# and happily use the API - variations of that provided by Betfair. But I have a question on considering trying some bflw implementation. On RunnerChange trd is aggregate volume at price since start of market. I think I’m right. I can handle that OK but curious if bflw does that already to deliver change in trade volume at each change point? Simulating trading (how I do it) needs to know volume executed at a time point so how does bflw handle this?

elements.text: Hi. I’m a non bflw user at the moment. My coding strength is C# and happily use the API - variations of that provided by Betfair. But I have a question on considering trying some bflw implementation. On RunnerChange trd is aggregate volume at price since start of market. I think I’m right. I can handle that OK but curious if bflw does that already to deliver change in trade volume at each change point? Simulating trading (how I do it) needs to know volume executed at a time point so how does bflw handle this?

text: It just provides what betfair gives so will be since the start, however calculating the delta between updates is relatively easy

elements.text: It just provides what betfair gives so will be since the start, however calculating the delta between updates is relatively easy

text: Have you thought a about incorporating the delta in your framework? How do you backtest available volume that can be traded otherwise?

elements.text: Have you thought a about incorporating the delta in your framework? How do you backtest available volume that can be traded otherwise?

text: It’s a wrapper so doesn't, flumine is the framework and does via the simulated middleware

elements.text: It’s a wrapper so doesn't, flumine is the framework and does via the simulated middleware

text:
Thanks for clarification. That’s probably what I was referring to.

And so a follow up simulation related question is for a rule of thumb for proportion of volume matched? It can’t be necessarily assumed you’d match against all traded volume in the historical record, even ignoring market impact effects, nor assume you’d always make top of the queue. Financial market modellers apply assumptions of a trade share as non-impacting and wondering what considerations may be made in this instance (obviously not in flumine).

elements.text: Thanks for clarification. That’s probably what I was referring to.

And so a follow up simulation related question is for a rule of thumb for proportion of volume matched? It can’t be necessarily assumed you’d match against all traded volume in the historical record, even ignoring market impact effects, nor assume you’d always make top of the queue. Financial market modellers apply assumptions of a trade share as non-impacting and wondering what considerations may be made in this instance (obviously not in flumine).
